metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Node.js MongoDB Update
Update Document
You can update a record, or document as it is called in MongoDB, by using the updateOne() method.
content.html: You can update a record, or document as it is called in MongoDB, by using the updateOne() method.

content.text: The first parameter of the updateOne() method is a query object defining which document to update.
content.html: The first parameter of the updateOne() method is a query object defining which document to update.

content.text: Note: If the query finds more than one record, only the first occurrence is updated.
content.html: Note: If the query finds more than one record, only the first occurrence is updated.

content.text: The second parameter is an object defining the new values of the document.
content.html: The second parameter is an object defining the new values of the document.

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  var myquery = { address: "Valley 345" };
  var newvalues = { $set: {name: "Mickey", address: "Canyon 123" } };
  dbo.collection("customers").updateOne(myquery, newvalues, function(err, res) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log("1 document updated");
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_update_one.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_update_one.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_update_one.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:
Update Only Specific Fields
When using the $set operator, only the specified fields are updated:
content.html: When using the $set operator, only the specified fields are updated:

content.text: Update Many Documents
To update all documents that meets the criteria of the query, use the updateMany() method.
content.html: To update all documents that meets the criteria of the query, use the updateMany() method.

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  var myquery = { address: /^S/ };
  var newvalues = {$set: {name: "Minnie"} };
  dbo.collection("customers").updateMany(myquery, newvalues, function(err, res) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(res.result.nModified + " document(s) updated");
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_update_many.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_update_many.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_update_many.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:
The Result Object
The updateOne() and the updateMany() methods return an object which contains information about how the execution affected the database.
content.html: The updateOne() and the updateMany() methods return an object which contains information about how the execution affected the database.

content.text: Most of the information is not important to understand, but one object inside the object is called "result" which tells us if the execution went OK, and how many documents were affected.
content.html: Most of the information is not important to understand, but one object inside the object is called "result" which tells us if the execution went OK, and how many documents were affected.

content.text: The result object looks like this:

content.code_html: { n: 1, nModified: 2, ok: 1 }

content.text: You can use this object to return the number of updated documents:
content.html: You can use this object to return the number of updated documents:
